div.l: Thouȝ þᵗat my tale be of an hostillere
But natheles I wil not telle it ȝit
But or we departe I wis þᵘou shalt be quyt
And þerwith al he lowgh and made chere
And saide his tale as ye shul aftir here
Here endith þe cokis prolog and

¶ Cookbegynneth his
¶ tale
A Prentys whilom duelt yn oᵘur cite
Of acraft of vitaillers was he
As gailard he was as goldfinych in þᵉ shawe
Broun as a bery a proꝑper felawe
With lokkis I kembid ful fetously
Daunce he coude wel and iolili
That he was clepid Perkyn Revelour
He was as ful of love and paramour
As is the hyve ful of hony swete
Wel was þe wenche þᵗat with him myȝte slepe
And at eueri bridale wolde he synge ⁊and hoppe
He lovid bettir þe nethir ende þan þe shoppe
For when þer eny riding was in chepe
Out of þe shoppe thider wolde he lepe
Til þat he hadde al þe siȝte I seyn
And daunsed wel he wolde not come ayen̄
And gadrid him a meyne of his sort
To hoppe and synge and make such disport
And þere þey sette stevene forto mete
To pleyyn at þe dys in such a strete
For in þe toun was þer no prentys
That fairer coude caste a peire of dys
Than Perkyn coude and þerto he was fre
Of his dispence in place of priuite
That fond his maister wel in his chaffare
For ofte tyme he fond his box ful bare
For shortly a prentis þat is A Revelour
That hauntith dys Riot and paramour͗e
His maister shal it in his shoppe Abie
Al haue he no part of þe mynstralsie
For thefte and riot þey be conuertibill
